senses.ex: He wrote a comprehensive report on the event.

Tips.title: Complete Overview
Tips.description: Use 'comprehensive' to show nothing was missed in an analysis or report.
Tips.example: Her comprehensive review covered every chapter.

Tips.title: Not Always Positive
Tips.description: 'Comprehensive' may imply a work is too long or complex.
Tips.example: The comprehensive manual confused the new employees.

Tips.title: Expect Depth
Tips.description: Something 'comprehensive' is expected to cover minor details too.
Tips.example: The documentary offers a comprehensive look at the issue.

senses.de: Having a wide scope or covering a lot.
senses.ex: The university offers a comprehensive curriculum.

Tips.title: Wide-Ranging Content
Tips.description: Use 'comprehensive' to describe content that spans various areas or subjects.
Tips.example: The library's comprehensive collection spans millennia.

Tips.title: Impressive Scope
Tips.description: It's good to express the impressive range of something ambitious or large.
Tips.example: This comprehensive history book covers every war era.

senses.ex: The exam will test your comprehensive understanding of the subject.

Tips.title: Deep Knowledge
Tips.description: Shows a very deep understanding when learning or explaining something.
Tips.example: You need a comprehensive grasp of laws to succeed in this course.

Tips.title: Shows Mastery
Tips.description: Indicates strong command over a skill, subject, or field.
Tips.example: His comprehensive knowledge of programming landed him the job.

senses.ex: His car is covered by a comprehensive insurance policy.

Tips.title: Not Basic
Tips.description: Comprehensive insurance isn't basic; it includes multiple types of coverages.
Tips.example: We opted for comprehensive insurance for better protection.

Tips.title: Financial Security
Tips.description: 'Comprehensive' in insurance means more financial security against damage.
Tips.example: The comprehensive plan covers both theft and accidents.

senses.de: Relating to an educational system that doesn't separate students based on ability.
senses.ex: She studies at a comprehensive school.

Tips.title: Equality in Education
Tips.description: Reflects an educational approach where students learn together, regardless of ability.
Tips.example: Comprehensive schools aim to provide equal opportunities for all.

Tips.title: All Abilities
Tips.description: Comprehensive education means teaching students of mixed abilities in one system.
Tips.example: Comprehensive education focuses on inclusive learning experiences.

Broad.wordDefinition:
Broad means covering a large or wide area without including too many details or specifics. For example, a broad overview of a topic would give a general idea of what it's about without going into too much depth.

Broad can describe a range of things, such as a broad smile or a broad spectrum of colors.

So while both words refer to covering a lot of ground, broad is used when you want to describe something on a high level, while comprehensive is used when you want to describe something in great detail.

Complete.wordDefinition:
Complete means that something has all the parts or elements that it needs to be considered finished, but it doesn't necessarily mean that it includes every possible detail.

For example, a complete set of books may contain all the volumes in the series, but it might not include every special edition or variant cover.

Complete means having all the parts needed, while comprehensive means having all the parts and every tiny detail included.

Detail.wordDefinition:
Comprehensive means covering a lot of information or a wide range of topics, while detail refers to the specific parts or aspects of something.

Detail is more suited for describing specific parts or features of something, such as providing details about the plot of a book or the ingredients in a recipe.

Essentially, comprehensive refers to the overall picture, while detail is about the specific pieces that make up that picture.

Encyclopedic.wordDefinition:
Comprehensive means covering everything or all aspects of something, while encyclopedic refers to containing a lot of information on many subjects.

Comprehensive is generally used when referring to a single topic or subject, while encyclopedic refers to a collection of information on many different topics.

For example, a comprehensive book on mathematics would cover all aspects of mathematics in great detail. An encyclopedic book would contain a lot of information on mathematics as well as many other topics like history, science, literature, and many more.

Exhaustive.wordDefinition:
Exhaustive means including everything or the smallest details.

It describes something that is extremely thorough and leaves no stone unturned. For example, an exhaustive search for information would leave absolutely no information untouched and looked at everything in exhaustive detail.

In summary, both words describe a thorough approach, but comprehensive indicates coverage of everything that is important or relevant, while exhaustive indicates that every insignificant detail is combed through as well.

Extensive.wordDefinition:
Comprehensive means including everything or nearly everything, while extensive means covering a large area, distance, or range.

Extensive would be more applicable when referring to something that covers a large physical area or involves a broad quantity of items.

For instance, one might say that a large forest has an extensive range of trees, or that someone has extensive knowledge of a particular topic.

Inclusive.wordDefinition:
Comprehensive means covering all aspects or elements of something, while inclusive means encompassing all groups or types of people.

Inclusive can be applied to policies or practices that welcome and accommodate diverse groups of people, such as an inclusive workplace that values and respects people of different backgrounds and identities.

Comprehensive refers to completeness in terms of coverage, while inclusive pertains to diversity and being welcoming of all people.

Systematic.wordDefinition:
Comprehensive means complete, inclusive or covering everything, while systematic means organized or methodical.

A systematic approach to studying for an exam would mean organizing your notes, creating a schedule, and sticking to it in order to cover all the necessary material in a structured way.

So, in general, comprehensive describes something that includes everything or is all-encompassing, while systematic describes a methodical approach to achieving a particular goal.

Thorough.wordDefinition:
Comprehensive means including everything, while thorough means complete and detailed.

Thorough is used when something is done with great attention to detail, leaving no stone unturned. For example, a thorough cleaning of a room would involve cleaning not just the surface but also corners, under furniture, and every nook and cranny.

To summarize, comprehensive refers to a wide range of things being included, while thorough refers to depth and attention to detail.

quotes.Text: A character on stage who can present no convincing argument or information as to his past experience, his present behaviour or his aspirations, nor give a comprehensive analysis of his motives, is as legitimate and as worthy of attention as one who, alarmingly, can do all these things.
quotes.Title: English Dramatist
quotes.Name: Harold Pinter

quotes.Text: Women who may choose to have silicone breast implants are entitled to independent research to ensure they have complete and comprehensive information. It's especially important since so many women have experienced complications with their implants they never knew were possible.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Gene Green

quotes.Text: I... now see a rare opportunity to push across the goal line much of the unfinished business of America: investing in our infrastructure and workers, universal healthcare, comprehensive immigration reform and scrubbing a tax code that's out of shape and behind the times.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Xavier Becerra

quotes.Text: We were right to make the case for the U.K. to negotiate a comprehensive customs union with the E.U. And we are right to argue for a strong single market deal, based on common standards, protections and regulations: the right balance of rights and obligation.
quotes.Title: British Politician
quotes.Name: Keir Starmer

quotes.Text: We should put hardworking families first by voting on legislation to create jobs, raise wages, provide equal pay for women, invest in education, protect voting rights, and pass comprehensive immigration reform.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Jan Schakowsky

quotes.Text: I cherish the creation of public space and services, especially health, housing and the comprehensive education system which dared to give so many of us ideas 'above our station.
quotes.Title: British Activist
quotes.Name: Frances O'Grady

quotes.Text: I'm always willing to have a conversation about strengthening our national security in a long-term, comprehensive, and cost-effective manner.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Abigail Spanberger

quotes.Text: I still passionately support comprehensive immigration reform legislation with a path to full and equal citizenship.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Hillary Clinton

quotes.Text: I am deeply concerned for the safety of our people brought by a lack of a comprehensive strategy to defeat ISIL.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Joni Ernst

quotes.Text: Actually, I'm a strong supporter of comprehensive tax reform.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: John S. Watson
